title: After the protests: solutions to end black deaths in custody
description: Protests around Australia have been calling for action to end black deaths in custody. Indigenous families, legal organisations and academics say that solutions to this problem have been put forward time and time again, only to be ignored.In this episode of Full Story, black deaths in custody advocate Latoya Rule, and academic Thalia Anthony explore some immediate solutions to end black deaths in custody.
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Miles Herbert, Ellen Leabeaterand Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson.

title: The death of David Dungay Jnr
description: One of the names chanted in the Australian protests sparked by the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis has been David Dungay. The eerie similarities between his case and the death of Floyd have brought his death in 2015 back into the spotlight. Both men were held down before they died, both cried ‘I can’t breathe’. Miles Herbert looks back at the death of David Dungay Jnr
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Miles Herbert. Produced by Joe Koning. The executive producers are Lorena Allam, Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: New data on the unfair policing of Indigenous people
description: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander adults make up 2% of the national population but at least 27% of the prison population. Michael McGowan looks at the data behind one offence that drives the disproportionate incarceration of First Nations people
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Michael McGowan. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: A journey into Antarctica: the unavoidable signs of global heating
description: The effects of global heating are in evidence everywhere across the islands of Antarctica – from penguin colonies to melting glaciers. The Guardian’s global environment editor Jonathan Watts witnessed how conditions are changing quickly
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Jonathan Watts. Produced by Cheeka Eyers, Joshua Kelly and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson

title: Unreliable data: how a tiny US company influenced Covid-19 policy globally
description: In May a single study published in one of the world’s leading medical journals led to trials of a possible coronavirus treatment being halted around the world. Weeks later the study was retracted and the company behind the data used is facing serious scrutiny. Melissa Davey tells us how it all unravelled
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Melissa Davey. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: The protests shaking America after the death of George Floyd
description: Guardian US reporter Kenya Evelyn looks back at the 11 days of protest that started in Minneapolis over the killing of George Floyd but quickly spread across the rest of America and then the world.
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys and reported by Kenya Evelyn. Produced by Courtney Yusuf and Axel Kacoutié. Executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: What will 21,000 job losses mean for Australia's universities?
description: One of the first sectors to feel the hit of the pandemic in Australia is our universities. With international students making up more than a quarter of all students and paying high fees that are essential to many university budgets, what does the future look like for universities? Today we examine the value of these jobs by talking to one of the people to lose university work
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Elias Visontay. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Australia’s shameful record on black deaths in custody
description: In the wake of widespread protests in the United States after the killing of George Floyd by the police, people are now taking to the streets in Australia. Their goal is to show solidarity with black communities in America, and highlight Australia’s problems with police violence and institutional racism. In this episode Indigenous affairs editor Lorena Allam examines Australia’s record on Indigenous deaths in custody.
contributors: Hosted by Laura Murphy-Oates  and reported by Lorena Allam. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: The death of George Floyd: will anything change in the US?
description: Protests have exploded across the US after a video showed Derek Chauvin, a white Minneapolis police officer, kneeling on the neck of George Floyd, an African American man, despite his pleas that he could not breathe. Floyd lost consciousness and died. Paul Butler discusses the history of police killings of black Americans and whether Floyd’s death could be a turning point
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Paul Butler. Produced by Joshua Kelly and Axel Kacoutié. Executive producers are NNicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates.

title: Is it too late to save the Great Barrier Reef?
description: This summer, the world’s largest coral reef system, the Great Barrier Reef, suffered the worst mass bleaching outbreak ever witnessed. Graham Readfearn looks at whether people are ready to accept the reality that at least 70% of the world’s coral reefs will soon be lost
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Graham Readfearn. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. Executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Hong Kong: the end of one country, two systems?
description: Protesters have take to the streets again, this time over a national security law that is set to be imposed by Beijing. A Guardian reporter in Hong Kong and Lily Kuo look at how the standoff compares with those of Hong Kong’s recent history
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys and reported by Lily Kuo. Produced by Sam Colbert and Axel Kacoutié. Executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates and Joe Koning

title: How a national security law is leading to secret trials in Australia
description: Last week, in a courthouse in Canberra, reporters were handed a statement by the defendant as they walked out the door. It simply read “I am unable to say much and you are unable to report much, this is the state of our now fragile democracy”. In this episode of Full Story, reporter Christopher Knaus explains how this trial came about, and the law that’s allowed this story to be shrouded in secrecy.
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Christopher Knaus. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. Executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: The killing of Ahmaud Arbery
description: On 23 February Ahmaud Arbery, a young black man, was shot dead by two white men in Brunswick, Georgia. But it was only when a 36-second video of the killing was leaked on 5 May, generating nationwide outcry, that three men were charged with his murder. Why did it take so long?
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Sam Levine and Khushbu Shah. Produced by Sam Colbert and AAxel Kacoutié. Executive producers Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard

title: The rise and fall of Alan Jones, Australia's leading shock jock
description: This week one of the country’s most successful radio presenters will broadcast his final show. For some, Alan Jones was a frank and fearless voice, for others, a divisive and polarising force in the media landscape. Guardian Australia’s media reporter, Amanda Meade, explores his legacy
contributors: Reported by Amanda Meade and presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and  Joe Koning. Executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson.

title: Does the Covidsafe app work?
description: The Covidsafe app, rolled out in late April, was sold to the Australian public as a measure that would ‘save lives and protect lives’. On this episode of Full Story, reporter Josh Taylor explores a series of flaws in the app that are causing problems for users, and for at least one state health authority.
contributors: Reported by Josh Taylor and presented byLaura Murphy-Oates Produced by Ellen Leabeaterand Joe Koning.  Executive producers are Miles Martignoniand Gabrielle Jackson.

title: The scientific race to understand Covid-19
description: In the five months since the world learned about Covid-19, it has killed hundreds of thousands of people. In that time, what have scientists found out – and what do they still not know?
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Robin McKie. Produced by Mythili Rao and Axel Kacoutié. Executive producers Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard.

title: Australia’s muddled energy policy and the roadmap to nowhere
description: Political editor Katharine Murphy talks to environment editor Adam Morton about a huge week in energy policy and why Australia appears to be making an energy roadmap without a destination
contributors: Reported by Katharine Murphy and Adam Morton. Hosted and produced by Laura Murphy-Oates. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: How the Mosquito Army saved one NSW town from the bushfires
description: Last Australian summer as the bushfires swept through the south coast of New South Wales, the small town of Mongarlowe found itself in the path of an enormous blaze, with very little resources to fight it. To save the town, the residents banded together and formed a very special firefighting crew – the Mosquito Army
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Alice Ansara. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. Executive producers Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: The push for prisoners in Australia to be released in case of second Covid-19 wave
description: As lockdowns ease around the country, Laura Murphy-Oates speaks to prison staff and prison reform advocates who are concerned about a potential second wave of Covid-19 that could quickly spread through prisons and put the Indigenous population, and other vulnerable people at risk
contributors: Presented and reported by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. Executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: How an audacious coup attempt in Venezuela backfired
description: An attempt earlier this month to remove Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro from power ended in farcical failure as a seaborne invading force was captured easily following a series of mishaps. World affairs editor Julian Borger tells the bizarre story
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Julian Borger. Produced by Joshua Kelly and Axel Kacoutié. Executive producers Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates and Joe Koning
